results.title: Dogwatch
results.creator_credit: Laurie McInnes, Richard Brennan, Black Ray Films, Smile Production and AFFC
results.brief_description: From the director of “Broken Highway”, “Dogwatch” is a thriller set at sea aboard a rusty cargo ship with equally as dubious a crew. Captained by alcoholic and corrupt skipper (Steven Vidler) aka ‘The Judas Captain’, the doomed ship is to be sunk by Heckle, the first mate (John Brumpton) once the captain has navigated the vessel to deep waters - all paid for by Triad gangsters. The hapless (sometimes farcical) crew and mysteriously cryptic Palmer (Russell Kiefel) make the journey unbearable for the captain. Stopping off to do a bit of gun smuggling in exchange for gold, the crew discover a stench in the hold and as one crew member points out ‘The Triad’ that organised this cruise won’t be expecting anyone to return. Mutiny and murder take over the minds of the crew as each man tries to assert his will and survive the situation in which they find themselves. Written and directed by Laurie McInnes. Cast includes Richard Carter, Joel Edgerton, John Alansu, Yaw Glymin.

results.title: Dogtown and Z-Boys
results.creator_credit: Agi Orsi Productions, Vans (US), Stacy Peralta and Craig Stecyk
results.brief_description: This award-winning, thrilling story is about a group of discarded kids who revolutionized skateboarding and shaped the attitude and culture of modern day extreme sports. Featuring old skool skating footage, exclusive interviews and a blistering rock soundtrack, DOGTOWN AND Z-BOYS captures the rise of the Zephyr skateboarding team from Venice’s Dogtown, a tough “locals only” beach with a legacy of outlaw surfing.

constellations_other.name: Skate or die
constellations_other.description: Skateboarding is a subculture frequently documented, from amateur skate videos filmed with fish-eye lenses, to documentaries exploring the genesis of the subculture and gritty feature films depicting underlying social dynamics.

results.creator_credit_for_label: Agi Orsi Productions, Vans (US), Stacy Peralta and Craig Stecyk

results.title: Dogtown and Z-boys
results.creator_credit: Stacy Peralta, Agi Orsi, Vans Off The Wall and AOP
results.brief_description: 1975 and in a slum area of Santa Monica, California, was located a rough neighbourhood know as Dogtown. In Dogtown, twelve teenage friends, many from broken homes, zealously surfed their dilapidated well-protected turf. Known as the Zephyr Boys - or Z-Boys for short - these teenage boys and one girl, applied their well-honed surfing skills to skateboarding and a fad that had all but died out was reborn. Fuelled by competitive drive and pushing each other to perform increasingly daring feats, the crew were inspired when a chronic drought left innumerable swimming pools empty. It was in these empty pools that the Z-Boys skated (illegally) and devised unheard of manoeuvres, revolutionising the sport. When “Skateboarder” magazine chronicled their audacious adventures, fame and notoriety beckoned. Whilst competing in the revived National Skateboarder Championships, the tricks performed wowed those present and the Z-Boys ruled. This documentary uses extensive stills and footage from the era (some of it quite astounding) and intersperses it with contemporary interviews with the Z-boys, who reminisce about their glory days and the forces that shaped their destiny. MTV style editing, a plenitude of vintage material and a rocking soundtrack (including Ted Nugent, Black Sabbath, Led Zepplin The Stooges and Jimi Hendrix) makes for great viewing.

results.title: Dogs, cats and rabbits
results.brief_description: An amusing animated non-narrated film in three parts. Part one: 41 Barks - animated impressions of dogs, drawn and barked by Eliot Noyes Jr. Part two: Catsup - by Lana Hoban with music “Alley cat” by Frank Bjorn, played by Bent Fabric and a cast of five cats Part three: Rabbits, texture, shape and fun with drawings by Bill Stitt. Suitable for primary school level.

results.title: Dogs in space [NTSC]
results.creator_credit: Richard Lowenstein, Glenys Rowe, Burrowes Film Group and Entertainment Media
results.brief_description: A group of young people enjoy the summer of 1979 in the belief that they will never grow up and join the adult world. Action centres on a Melbourne household of punks, hippies, students and radicals who represent the counter culture and the punk generation living on sex, drugs, rock ‘n’ roll and television. Cast includes Michael Hutchence of INXS, Saskia Post, Nique Needles, Chris Haywood, Gary Foley, Joe Camilleri, Noah Taylor.

results.title: Dogs in Space
results.brief_description: Melbourne, Australia 1978. The punk phenomenon is sweeping the country and Dogs In Space, a punk group, are part of it. A ragtag collection of outcasts live in a squat, surviving on a diet of old TV space films, drugs and good music.

constellations_other.name: Aboriginal History Archive
constellations_other.description: The Aboriginal History Archive at Victoria University, led by Gary Foley, is dedicated to the collection and preservation of First Peoples' stories and cultural material. The political activism of the Black Power movement in the 1970s is intersected with representation of Aboriginal actors on screen.

constellations_other.name: Jill Bilcock
constellations_other.description: An editor’s work often goes unnoticed, but they’re scene-stitching not only brings the director’s vision to life but sometimes steals the show. One of Australia’s greatest editors, Jill Bilcock, has shaped some of the country’s most memorable screen stories.

constellations_other.name: Jan Chapman
constellations_other.description: From an independent Sydney cinema to the world's stage, Jan Chapman's work has many connections to the Australian film scene and Hollywood.

results.description:
Set in a share-house occupied by a collection of social misfits, the film focuses on the tumultuous affair between vivacious Anna (Saskia Post) and drug-taking Sam (Michael Hutchence), front man for the band Dogs in Space.

In his first on-screen role, Hutchence pushed against his established public persona.

As the charismatic, sexually charged front man for Australian mainstream rockers INXS, he had legions of fans that were banned from seeing their teen rock idol when the film received an R18+ rating.

With the aid of cinematographer Andrew de Groot’s invaluable camerawork, Lowenstein achieves an intense, fluid evocation of a squalid, destructive lifestyle.

Featuring a sensational post-punk soundtrack courtesy of Iggy Pop, Boys Next Door (aka Birthday Party), Brian Eno and Gang of Four, Dogs in Space has been described by Jennie Kermode in Eye for Film as “less of a film and more of an experience, a poem rather than a conventional story. It’s a remarkable testament to a piece of Australian history most people prefer to ignore.”
description_for_label:

constellations_other.name: Black Power through film and TV
constellations_other.description: The Black Power movement of the late 1960s and early 70s was “the most exciting and dynamic era in modern Indigenous history” according to Aboriginal activist Professor Gary Foley, who gained widespread attention for protests during the time and later leveraged film and TV to fight for Indigenous rights.

results.title: Dogs
results.creator_credit: Lex Van Os and FM-TV Entertainment
results.brief_description:
Episode of Series “Talk to the animals”.
In response to thousands of requests, the producers of Seven Network’s “Talk to the animals” have compiled this videotape for dog lovers of all ages. Now you can enjoy your favourite dog stories from Australia’s most popular television series again and again. Hosted by Dr. Harry Cooper.

results.title: Dogs
results.brief_description: Explores the world of dogs and their relationships with humans. Indicates that dog ownership means responsibility and care and that humans can learn a lot about animal behaviour by closely observing their pets. Also shows dogs that herd sheep, help police and blind people and perform tricks.
